Experience Cluster Systems Software Engineer Intel Corporation July 2013  – Present (2 years 2 months) Champaign, IL Around early July of this year, I transitioned from the Atom team to Intel Cluster Ready team.  
 
My "official" job description includes ->  
 
- developing cluster reference designs for Intel Xeon and Intel Xeon Phi based solutions 
- prototyping and developing innovative features for cluster system software components 
- providing rapid response and support for stakeholders 
 
 
On a day to day basis, my work involves developing working knowledge of HPC cluster systems software components, related hardware components and HPC cluster programming models. I work directly with senior engineering staff building softwares and improving systems debugging skills. I get to play with cluster solutions integration, Linux system administration, cluster provisioning tools, resource management middlewares, different parallel programming models and different cluster interconnect fabrics. System Validation Engineer Intel Corporation March 2012  –  July 2013  (1 year 5 months) Austin, Texas In my first stint with Intel, I worked in Atom Validation Engineering team within Intel's Architecture Group. I got to dabble with the internals of Intel's 32nm and 22nm Atom phone and tablet SoCs.  
 
My "official" job description is as follows ->  
 
Created, defined and developed system validation environment and test suites. Used and applied emulation and platform-level tools and techniques to ensure performance to spec. Responsible for the development of methodologies, execution of validation plans, and debug of failures. Position requires a broad understanding of multiple system areas and requires interfacing with Architecture, Design, and Pre-silicon Validation teams in improving post-silicon test content and providing feedback for future on-die debug features 
 
My primary focus area was performance validation of the graphics core. This involved, among activities mentioned above, comparison of benchmark numbers between runs on emulation with theoretical limits, on bare firmware without any overheads and on an operating system mimicking "the real world", debugging and root causing the differences and sweeping through various system settings with the underlying goal of extracting maximum performance.  
 
The combination of system settings and benchmark comparisons could often run into the thousands. Given necessity is the mother of invention, I ended up developing a rudimentary Python based automation tool chain that would let me execute all my tests over an extended period of time, typically weekends, gather data, apply post processing scripts and have the results ready for analysis. I continued to work on a formal automation framework that would eventually end up being used by the entire team to automate various kinds of testing. I was the primary author on a variety of modules, such as modules that would reboot the platform, send emails with results and errors, monitor testing for time outs, decode memory type settings. Graduate Research Assistant Center for Computation and Technology, LSU 2008  –  March 2012  (4 years) Research on CPU accelerators, nVidia GPUs, OpenCL, benchmarking, Scientific computing, High Performance Computing, temperature and power monitoring, algorithm analysis, parallel programming, multithreaded programming, linear algebra, CUDA. 
 
Advisor: Dr. Thomas Sterling Undergraduate Research Assistant Center for Computation and Technology 2006  –  2008  (2 years) cluster construction, maintenance, documentation, troubleshooting, tech support, supercomputing research, high performance computing, program optimization, compiler optimization, performance tuning 
 
Advisor: Dr. Thomas Sterling Math tutor Center for Academic Success 2005  –  2008  (3 years) Assisted undergraduate students with mathematics courses, contributed to codes with Matlab, Mathematica and web based portals like WebAssign and 
MyMatlab to visualize graphs and ease learning process

Selected in Google Summer of Code 2006 program. Awarded $4500 for developing memory compression patches for Linux kernel: http://compcache.googlecode.com/ 
Its now included in mainline. 
(Mentor: Rik Van Riel, Senior Software Engineer, Redhat). 
 
Developed memory allocator which is now part of Xen hypervisor (replacing its default xmalloc engine). Additional Honors & Awards Worked on a project selected in Google Summer of Code 2010 program (Memory Compression for Virtualized Environments). Awarded $5000 for successful completion.

Evaluating effects of cache memory compression on embedded systems. Linux Symposium, Ottawa, 2007. Paper: http://ols.108.redhat.com/2007/Reprints/briglia-Reprint.pdf 
 
Published article at LWN (Linux Weekly News): 
"Compcache: in-memory compressed swapping"

Summary Experienced electrical engineer with over sixteen years of industry experience currently working on Renewable Energy related products at Intel. 
 
In addition to holding a BS in Electronics Engineering, I recently graduated from Oregon Institute of Technology with a second Bachelors Degree in Renewable Energy Engineering. OIT is the only accredited institution in the country offering Bachelors and Masters programs in this advanced curriculum of energy system analysis and design; including energy efficient buildings and power systems such as solar thermal, PV, wind, geothermal, hydro-power and fuel cells. 
 
I have an extensive background in many diverse disciplines of electrical engineering and data networking. A solid ‘hands-on’ background in both Field and Test Engineering followed by extensive experience in product development gives me a distinct advantage in designing innovative solutions to modern energy system problems. As a successful first-time entrepreneur, I was responsible for the ground-up design, build-out and daily operations of the Portland area Internet Service Provider DSL-Only. 
 
These experiences led to over 10 years of private consulting in system architecture and design engineering at leading consulting firms - giving me valuable experience in customer-facing engineering roles.
